name: Saint Thaddaeus
shortDescription: Apostle known for asking Jesus about selective revelation, missionary to Armenia and Persia, and traditional author of the Epistle of Jude
longDescription: Saint Thaddaeus, also called Judas son of James, Lebbaeus, or Jude (not Iscariot), was one of the Twelve Apostles of Jesus Christ. He is distinguished from Judas Iscariot by his patronymic 'son of James' and appears in three of the four Gospel apostle lists. His most significant moment in the Gospels occurs at the Last Supper when he asked Jesus the profound theological question: 'Lord, how is it that you will manifest yourself to us, and not to the world?' (John 14:22). This question about selective divine revelation became central to understanding the intimate nature of Christ's relationship with believers. According to tradition, Thaddaeus carried the Gospel eastward to Edessa where he healed King Abgar V, who had written to Jesus requesting healing. The legendary 'Image of Edessa' (Mandylion) - a miraculous image of Christ's face - is associated with this mission. Thaddaeus later journeyed to Armenia with fellow apostle Simon the Zealot, where they are venerated as the founders of Armenian Christianity. Both apostles were martyred together in Persia, with Thaddaeus traditionally killed by axe, club, or halberd. Some church traditions identify him as the author of the Epistle of Jude, which warns against false teachers and notably quotes the apocryphal Book of Enoch. His feast day is celebrated on October 28 (with Simon the Zealot) in Western Christianity and July 19 in Eastern traditions.

biography.earlyLife: Little known of early life; appears among the Twelve Apostles called by Jesus
biography.education: Trained as disciple by Jesus during three-year ministry

majorEvents.description: Selected by Jesus as one of the Twelve Apostles
At the Last Supper, asked Jesus: 'Lord, how is it that you will manifest yourself to us, and not to the world?' (John 14:22), prompting Jesus's teaching on the indwelling of the Trinity in believers
Received the Holy Spirit with the other apostles in the Upper Room
According to tradition, carried Jesus's reply and the miraculous Image of Edessa to King Abgar V, healing the king of his illness
Journeyed with Simon the Zealot to evangelize Armenia, converting many and establishing the Armenian Church
Martyred alongside Simon the Zealot in Persia (modern Iran), traditionally killed by axe, club, or halberd

achievements: One of the Twelve Apostles chosen by Christ
Asked the pivotal question about divine self-revelation
Founder of Armenian Christianity (with Simon the Zealot)
Healed King Abgar V of Edessa according to tradition
Traditional author of the Epistle of Jude
biography.legacy: Thaddaeus is venerated as a patron saint of Armenia and is associated with hopeless causes in some traditions. The Saint Thaddaeus Monastery in northwestern Iran marks the traditional site of his martyrdom and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. His question about revelation influenced Christian understanding of the intimate, personal nature of divine self-disclosure. The Epistle of Jude, if written by him, provides unique references to Jewish apocryphal literature including the Book of Enoch.

coreConcepts.name: Selective Divine Revelation
coreConcepts.description: Thaddaeus's question probed why Christ reveals himself intimately to believers but not openly to the world - Jesus answered that those who love him and keep his word receive the indwelling of Father and Son

coreConcepts.name: Contending for the Faith
coreConcepts.description: The Epistle of Jude (if authored by Thaddaeus) exhorts believers to 'contend earnestly for the faith once delivered to the saints' against false teachers

coreConcepts.name: Jewish Apocalyptic Heritage
coreConcepts.description: Jude's epistle uniquely quotes the Book of Enoch and references the Assumption of Moses, showing continuity with Jewish apocalyptic tradition

coreConcepts.name: Divine Judgment on Apostasy
coreConcepts.description: Jude warns of divine judgment using examples from Israel's history, fallen angels, and Sodom and Gomorrah

majorWorks.title: Epistle of Jude
majorWorks.description: Brief but powerful letter warning against false teachers who have 'crept in unnoticed,' invoking examples of divine judgment and quoting 1 Enoch's prophecy of the Lord's coming with ten thousands of holy ones
